text.0:
:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: Get our fact-checks of the week's most outrageous claims delivered straight to your WhatsApp inbox.

Subscribe in three easy steps:

:link: Click the link https://t.co/0baDsRbvkA
:input_numbers: Save our number
:mobile_phone: Send a message with your name. https://t.co/EgTTYIYCQ9
text.1:
:police_car_light: HOAX: An infographic shared on Facebook claiming that the World Health Organisation has outlined “brain-damaging habits” is fake.

:stethoscope: @WHO has distanced itself from the infographic, and the claims made in it are also false: https://t.co/XPifTwDUzo
text.2:
A tweet claiming that Nigeria’s Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala has been selected as Director-General of the World Trade Organisation is :cross_mark: FALSE.

:briefcase: Dr Okonjo-Iweala was shortlisted and will now move on to the final round of the selection process: https://t.co/UzAgQ5t0Bz
text.3:
A Facebook post claiming that the US has threatened to revoke the visa of Kenya's president is :cross_mark: FALSE.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: The statement cited in the claim reiterates support for free, fair, and inclusive elections but does not mention President Kenyatta: https://t.co/NTJgCd58zK
text.4:
:warning_selector: From a threat to revoke a president's visa to a fake infographic of "brain-damaging habits", it's been another busy week of myth-busting for our fact-checkers.

:newspaper: Here are our top stories from the past seven days:
